Metadata.Source: Cambridge International AS & A Level Mathematics: Pure Mathematics 2 Past Paper
Metadata.Subject: MATH

QuestionContent.Text: The polynomial \(p(x)\) is defined by \[p(x) = ax^3 + bx - 10,\] where \(a\) and \(b\) are constants.\\It is given that \((x + 2)\) is a factor of \(p(x)\) and that the remainder is \(-55\) when \(p(x)\) is divided by \((x + 3)\).\\\\(a) Find the values of \(a\) and \(b\).\\\\(b) Hence factorise \(p(x)\) completely.

Parts.Solution: Using the factor theorem, substitute \(x = -2\) into \(p(x)\) and equate to zero:\\\[-8a - 2b - 10 = 0.\]\\Using the remainder theorem, substitute \(x = -3\) into \(p(x)\) and equate to \(-55\):\\\[-27a - 3b - 10 = -55.\]\\Solve the simultaneous equations:\\\[-8a - 2b = 10\] \[-27a - 3b = -45.\]\\Multiply the first equation by 3 and the second by 2 to eliminate \(b\):\\\[-24a - 6b = 30\] \[-54a - 6b = -90.\]\\Subtract:\\\[30a = 120.\]\\\[a = 4.\]\\Substitute \(a = 4\) into the first equation:\\\[-8(4) - 2b = 10.\]\\\[-32 - 2b = 10.\]\\\[-2b = 42.\]\\\[b = -21.\]
Parts.MarkingScheme: M1 for substitution into \(p(x)\), DM1 for solving simultaneous equations, A1 for \(a = 4\), A1 for \(b = -21\).
M1 for dividing by \((x + 2)\), A1 for quadratic factor, A1 for complete factorisation.

Metadata.Source: Cambridge International AS & A Level Mathematics: Pure Mathematics 2 Past Paper
Metadata.Subject: MATH

QuestionContent.Text: (a) Sketch, on the same diagram, the graphs of \(y = x + 3\) and \(y = |2x - 1|\).\\\\(b) Solve the equation \(x + 3 = |2x - 1|\).\\\\(c) Find the value of \(y\) such that \(5^{\frac{1}{y}} + 3 = |2 \times 5^{\frac{1}{y}} - 1|\). Give your answer correct to 3 significant figures.

Parts.Solution: Draw the V-shaped graph for \(y = |2x - 1|\), ensuring the vertex is at \(x = 0.5\) and it crosses the y-axis.\\Draw the straight line graph \(y = x + 3\) with a positive gradient, intersecting \(y = |2x - 1|\).
Parts.MarkingScheme: B1 for drawing \(y = |2x - 1|\), B1 for correctly intersecting \(y = x + 3\).
B1 for setting \(x + 3 = |2x - 1|\) into two cases, M1 for solving equations, A1 for \(x = 4\) and \(x = -\frac{2}{3}\).
M1 for substituting and using logarithms, A1 for correct \(y = 1.72\).

Metadata.QuestionTitle: Stationary Point of a Trigonometric Curve
Metadata.Source: Cambridge International AS & A Level Mathematics: Pure Mathematics 2 Past Paper
Metadata.Subject: MATH

QuestionContent.Text: The curve with equation \(y = 5x - 2\tan 2x\)\\\\Has exactly one stationary point in the interval \(0 < x < \frac{\pi}{4}\).\\\\Find the coordinates of this stationary point, giving each coordinate correct to 3 significant figures.

Parts.Solution: Differentiate \(y = 5x - 2\tan 2x\):\\\[\frac{dy}{dx} = 5 - 4\sec^2(2x).\]\\\\Set \(\frac{dy}{dx} = 0\) for a stationary point:\\\[5 - 4\sec^2(2x) = 0.\]\\\\Solve for \(\sec^2(2x)\):\\\[\sec^2(2x) = \frac{5}{4}.\]\\\\Use the identity \(\sec^2(2x) = 1 + \tan^2(2x)\):\\\[1 + \tan^2(2x) = \frac{5}{4}.\]\\\[\tan^2(2x) = \frac{1}{4}.\]\\\[\tan(2x) = \pm \frac{1}{2}.\]\\\\Since \(0 < x < \frac{\pi}{4}\), \(\tan(2x) > 0\):\\\[\tan(2x) = \frac{1}{2}.\]\\\[2x = \arctan\left(\frac{1}{2}\right).\]\\\[x = \frac{1}{2}\arctan\left(\frac{1}{2}\right).\]\\\\Evaluate \(x\) to 3 significant figures:\\\[x = 0.232.\]\\\\Substitute \(x = 0.232\) into \(y = 5x - 2\tan(2x)\):\\\[y = 5(0.232) - 2\tan(2(0.232)).\]\\\[y = 1.16 - 2(0.5) = 0.159.\]\\\\Stationary point coordinates are:\\\[(0.232, 0.159).\]
Parts.MarkingScheme: M1 for differentiation of \(y\), A1 for correct \(\frac{dy}{dx}\), M1 for solving \(\sec^2(2x)\), A1 for correct value of \(x\), A1 for substituting into \(y\), A1 for final coordinates \((0.232, 0.159)\).

Metadata.Source: Cambridge International AS & A Level Mathematics: Pure Mathematics 2 Past Paper
Metadata.Subject: MATH

QuestionContent.Text: Given that \[ \int_a^{a+14} \frac{1}{3x} \, dx = \ln 2, \] find the value of the positive constant \(a\).

Parts.Solution: The integral \[ \int \frac{1}{3x} \, dx \] simplifies to \[ \frac{1}{3} \ln x. \]\\\\Applying the limits, we have:\\\[ \frac{1}{3} \ln(a+14) - \frac{1}{3} \ln a = \ln 2. \]\\\\Using the logarithmic property \( \ln A - \ln B = \ln \frac{A}{B} \), this simplifies to:\\\[ \frac{1}{3} \ln \frac{a+14}{a} = \ln 2. \]\\\\Multiplying through by 3 to eliminate the fraction:\\\[ \ln \frac{a+14}{a} = 3 \ln 2. \]\\\\Using the property \( k \ln A = \ln A^k \), we rewrite:\\\[ \ln \frac{a+14}{a} = \ln 8. \]\\\\Equating the arguments of the logarithms:\\\[ \frac{a+14}{a} = 8. \]\\\\Simplifying:\\\[ a+14 = 8a. \]\\\[ 14 = 7a. \]\\\[ a = 2. \]
Parts.MarkingScheme: M1 for integrating to \( \frac{1}{3} \ln x \).\\A1 for correctly substituting limits to obtain \( \frac{1}{3} \ln(a+14) - \frac{1}{3} \ln a = \ln 2 \).\\M1 for using the logarithmic property \( \ln A - \ln B = \ln \frac{A}{B} \).\\M1 for applying \( k \ln A = \ln A^k \).\\A1 for solving to find \( a = 2 \).

Metadata.QuestionTitle: Gradient of the Normal to a Curve
Metadata.Source: Cambridge International AS & A Level Mathematics: Pure Mathematics 2 Past Paper
Metadata.Subject: MATH

QuestionContent.Text: A curve has equation \(x^2 + 4x\cos 3y = 6\).\\Find the exact value of the gradient of the normal to the curve at the point \((\sqrt{2}, \frac{\pi}{12})\).

Parts.Solution: Differentiate implicitly with respect to \(x\):\\\[2x + 4\cos 3y \frac{dy}{dx} - 12x \sin 3y \frac{dy}{dx} = 0.\]\\Rearrange to solve for \(\frac{dy}{dx}\):\\\[\frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{-2x}{4\cos 3y - 12x \sin 3y}.\]\\Substitute \(x = \sqrt{2}\) and \(y = \frac{\pi}{12}\):\\\[\frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{-2(\sqrt{2})}{4 \cos \frac{\pi}{4} - 12(\sqrt{2}) \sin \frac{\pi}{4}}.\]\\Simplify:\\\[\frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{-2\sqrt{2}}{4(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}) - 12\sqrt{2}(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}})}.\]\\\[\frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{-2\sqrt{2}}{2 - 12} = \frac{-2\sqrt{2}}{-10} = \frac{\sqrt{2}}{5}.\]\\The gradient of the normal is given by \(-\frac{1}{\frac{dy}{dx}}\):\\\[\text{Gradient of normal} = -\frac{1}{\frac{\sqrt{2}}{5}} = -\frac{5}{\sqrt{2}} = -\frac{5\sqrt{2}}{2}.\]
Parts.MarkingScheme: M1 for implicit differentiation, A1 for correct derivative.\\DM1 for substituting values of \(x\) and \(y\).\\M1 for finding gradient of normal.\\A1 for exact gradient \(-\frac{5\sqrt{2}}{2}\).

Metadata.Source: Cambridge International AS & A Level Mathematics: Pure Mathematics 2 Past Paper
Metadata.Subject: MATH

QuestionContent.Text: (a) By sketching a suitable pair of graphs on the same diagram, show that the equation \(\ln x = 2e^{-x}\) has exactly one root.\\(b) Verify by calculation that the root lies between 1.5 and 1.6.\\(c) Show that if a sequence of values given by the iterative formula \[x_{n+1} = e^{2e^{-x_n}}\] converges, then it converges to the root of the equation in part (a).\\(d) Use the iterative formula in part (c) to determine the root correct to 3 significant figures. Give the result of each iteration to 5 significant figures.

Parts.Solution: Draw the graphs of \(y = \ln x\) and \(y = 2e^{-x}\) on the same diagram.\\Indicate the intersection point where the root exists, showing that the two curves intersect exactly once.
Parts.MarkingScheme: B1 for correct sketch of \(y = \ln x\) and \(y = 2e^{-x}\).\\B1 for identifying the point of intersection and justifying one root.

Parts.Solution: Calculate \(\ln 1.5 - 2e^{-1.5} = -0.04\) and \(\ln 1.6 - 2e^{-1.6} = 0.06\).\\Since the values change sign between 1.5 and 1.6, the root lies in this interval.
Parts.MarkingScheme: M1 for evaluating \(\ln x - 2e^{-x}\) at 1.5 and 1.6.\\A1 for correct justification of the root in \([1.5, 1.6]\).

Parts.Solution: Replace \(x_{n+1}\) and \(x_n\) with \(x\) in the iterative formula and show that \(x = e^{2e^{-x}}\).\\This confirms that the iteration converges to the root of \(\ln x = 2e^{-x}\).
Parts.MarkingScheme: B1 for correct substitution and justification that the formula converges to the root.

Parts.Solution: Using the iterative formula, calculate successive values:\\\[x_1 = 1.5,\ x_2 = 1.54,\ x_3 = 1.543,\ \dots\]\\Continue until the root is correct to 3 significant figures as \(1.54\).
Parts.MarkingScheme: M1 for correct application of the iterative formula.\\A1 for obtaining the root to 3 significant figures.\\A1 for showing sufficient iterations to justify the result.

Metadata.Source: Cambridge International AS & A Level Mathematics: Pure Mathematics 2 Past Paper
Metadata.Subject: MATH

QuestionContent.Text: (a) Prove that \(4 \sin x \sin \left( x + \frac{\pi}{6} \right) \equiv \sqrt{3} - \sqrt{3} \cos 2x + \sin 2x\).\\\\(b) Find the exact value of \[\int_{0}^{\frac{5\pi}{6}} 4 \sin x \sin \left( x + \frac{\pi}{6} \right) dx.\]\\\\(c) Find the smallest positive value of \(y\) satisfying the equation \[4 \sin(2y) \sin \left(2y + \frac{\pi}{6} \right) = \sqrt{3}.\]\\Give your answer in an exact form.

Parts.Solution: Using the trigonometric identity for \(\sin A \sin B\):\\\[ \sin A \sin B = \frac{1}{2} \left[ \cos(A - B) - \cos(A + B) \right], \]\\substitute \(A = x\) and \(B = x + \frac{\pi}{6}\):\\\[ 4 \sin x \sin \left( x + \frac{\pi}{6} \right) = 2 \left[ \cos \left(x - \left(x + \frac{\pi}{6}\right)\right) - \cos \left(x + \left(x + \frac{\pi}{6}\right)\right) \right]. \]\\Simplify:\\\[ 2 \left[ \cos \left(-\frac{\pi}{6}\right) - \cos \left(2x + \frac{\pi}{6}\right) \right]. \]\\Using \(\cos(-\theta) = \cos \theta\) and \(\cos \frac{\pi}{6} = \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\):\\\[ 2 \left[ \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} - \cos \left(2x + \frac{\pi}{6}\right) \right]. \]\\Simplify further:\\\[ \sqrt{3} - \sqrt{3} \cos 2x + \sin 2x. \]\\Thus, \[ 4 \sin x \sin \left(x + \frac{\pi}{6}\right) \equiv \sqrt{3} - \sqrt{3} \cos 2x + \sin 2x. \]
Parts.MarkingScheme: B1 for stating the identity, M1 for correct substitution, A1 for simplifying to final form.

Parts.Solution: Using the result from part (a), integrate term by term:\\\[ \int_{0}^{\frac{5\pi}{6}} \left(\sqrt{3} - \sqrt{3} \cos 2x + \sin 2x\right) dx. \]\\Split the integral:\\\[ \sqrt{3} \int_{0}^{\frac{5\pi}{6}} 1 \, dx - \sqrt{3} \int_{0}^{\frac{5\pi}{6}} \cos 2x \, dx + \int_{0}^{\frac{5\pi}{6}} \sin 2x \, dx. \]\\Evaluate each term:\\\[ \sqrt{3} \left[ x \right]_{0}^{\frac{5\pi}{6}} = \sqrt{3} \left( \frac{5\pi}{6} - 0 \right) = \frac{5\sqrt{3}\pi}{6}. \]\\\[ -\sqrt{3} \int_{0}^{\frac{5\pi}{6}} \cos 2x \, dx = -\sqrt{3} \left[ \frac{\sin 2x}{2} \right]_{0}^{\frac{5\pi}{6}} = -\sqrt{3} \left( 0 - 0 \right) = 0. \]\\\[ \int_{0}^{\frac{5\pi}{6}} \sin 2x \, dx = \left[ -\frac{\cos 2x}{2} \right]_{0}^{\frac{5\pi}{6}} = \left( -\frac{\cos \frac{5\pi}{3}}{2} + \frac{1}{2} \right). \]\\Final value:\\\[ \frac{5\sqrt{3}\pi}{6} + 0 + \frac{1}{2}. \]
Parts.MarkingScheme: M1 for splitting the integral, A1 for correctly evaluating each term, A1 for final simplified value.

Parts.Solution: Using the given equation:\\\[ 4 \sin(2y) \sin \left(2y + \frac{\pi}{6}\right) = \sqrt{3}. \]\\Substitute the identity for \(\sin A \sin B\):\\\[ 2 \left[ \cos \left(-\frac{\pi}{6}\right) - \cos \left(4y + \frac{\pi}{6}\right) \right] = \sqrt{3}. \]\\Simplify and solve for \(y\):\\\[ \cos \left(4y + \frac{\pi}{6}\right) = \dots. \]\\Smallest \(y\): \[ y = \frac{\pi}{6}. \]
Parts.MarkingScheme: M1 for substituting identity, A1 for solving equation, A1 for exact smallest positive \(y\).
